newsitem.title: Czech republic: FOCUS - Czech plane maker mulls Taiwan venture.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Czech plane maker mulls Taiwan venture.

text.p: Czech aircraft producer, Aero Vodochoday a.s. said on Wednesday that talks with Taiwanese officials on Friday would focus on completing a deal to jointly develop the new AE-270 small commercial aircraft.

"We are preparing for Friday talks which should push forward the offer for completing the development and certification of the AE-270," Vladimir Nyvlt, executive director, of Aero Vodochody, told Reuters.
The AE-270, currently on the drawing board, is planned as a five to nine-seat, single-engine commercial plane.

Asked if the Taiwanese would join with Aero in actually building the plane, Nyvlt said, "Right now we are talking about development and certification, because we're talking about such a large financial amount that we are not able to cover alone."
He declined to say when the plane might go into production.
Earlier on Wednesday in Taipei, a senior Taiwanese aviation official said details in the talks such as the investment amount and the output were in the final stages.

Jack Tang, deputy director of the Taiwan Economics Ministry's Committee for Aviation and Space Industry told Reuters that if upcoming the talks with the Czechs went smoothly "we should reach an agreement in the near term".
A 23-member team comprising Taiwan officials and executives from aviation companies planned to visit the Czech Republic after this weeks airshow in Farnborough, Britain, he said.
"The Czechs hope to manufacture the jets in their country. If we do that, some parts will be produced in Taiwan," Tang said by telephone.
Taiwan has been seeking cooperation with foreign aerospace firms to produce regional passenger jets and boost its fledgling aerospace industry.
Aero, a unit of Aero Holding a.s. which is 62 percent owned by the Czech government, is looking for a way out of major financial difficulties.
The company has been actively seeking buyers for its upgraded L-159 "Albratross" light fighter aircraft, using advanced Rockwell avionics.
